name: NewYorker
text:
In 1959, when humans began measuring the carbon-dioxide concentration in the atmosphere, there was still some margin of time. This is no longer the case.
https://t.co/UHld9uxJYj

name: NewYorker
text: After Bill Buford had given up on ratatouille for many years, he learned a new recipe in a French kitchen. "I liked this one so much that I have made it every summer thereafter, without fail," he writes. https://t.co/cj0SX7hVhR

name: NewYorker
text: “Turning a corner, I came upon a small crowd facing a police cordon. Behind the oﬃcers, a dead body lay on the curb.” @lukemogelson reports from Portland, the epicenter of this summer’s unrest. https://t.co/r7uDj63uqY

name: NewYorker
text: If Joe Biden is not guarding his approval ratings for a second run, he could push for more stimulus money, expand and reform the courts, move money from the Pentagon to build out solar and wind power, and more. https://t.co/y34aqTXy8Z

name: NewYorker
text: As a corporate lawyer, Eugene Scalia repeatedly hindered the efforts of workers to secure beneﬁts or defend their rights. Now he is running President Trump's Department of Labor. https://t.co/2baYt0VoQ4

name: NewYorker
text:
Our electoral rights are debased by those who claim that America is a republic in order to justify siphoning power from the electorate, @SueHalpernVT writes.
https://t.co/nzPkIQlYM2

name: NewYorker
text: "Dude, do not write in a third party. Don't write in Kanye. It's not funny." Ilana Glazer discusses the 2020 election and her Web series “Cheat Sheet for the Voting Booth." Listen here. https://t.co/BYxXrDOgn7
